column4: The key to my mind here is "_eventually_ segfaults". Points to an occasional error, which often is memory...
a segmentation fault is an error generated by the OS to protect overall memory integrity, it is not hardware related
Yes. No question. I'm thinking collateral damage, however; once memory starts messing up, anything can happen.
the difference between a console and terminal is really a negligeable technicality, consoles are even called pseudo-terminals
so why do I have to log in to c/a/f2 when I'm already logged in to c/a/f7? There is no X screen associated with c/a/f2, which is why x commands don't work there...
I don't get your point...  c/a/f* are all different pseudo-ttys (or consoles as you may call)
nothing stops you from calling an X command from a different tty
How to explain? Calling an x command on tty2 will not affect the xserv on tty7. I believe ubuntu starts x only on tty7 ordinarily.
also, I believe I can log in as different users on tty2 and tty3 for instance
set your DISPLAY variable properly on any tty and calling an X command will open in your X
you can log in as a different user
these are different pseudo terminals
yes. I would not want my xserv on tty7 to be affected by what someone on tty2 does...
the X server rules are IP based, not tty based
if you don't have x actually running on tty2, trying to run something that expects gui will fail with "can't get screen". That's what was happening with ubentobox.
just try it instead of pointlessly arguing.... "export DISPLAY=YOUR-IP:0.0" and then type "xterm"
did that, earlier today, without the export step. thing is, ubentobox would have gotten the same desktop he has on tty7 if he had exported.
and he would have again been unable to set resolution. What worked for me was editing xconf with nano directly which can be done from a non-gui tty
the export part is just part of the current shell's environement and not related to the whole machine
you are right about editing the settings, but I'm following you less and less
pas de probleme... we've strayed pretty far afield. I propose we leave it alone.
